segments.text: with Mr. Fred Jaggi, Dr. Fred Jaggi.
Today's date is February 7th, 1980.
This is interview number two.
This is Terry Anderson.
This is our second interview with Dr. Fred Jackie.
Today's date is Thursday, February 7, 1980.
In 1937, you were appointed head of the newly established Department of Veterinary and Hygiene, a post which you had until 1949.
Why did they pick you?
Well, I don't know.
They'd never had anything like that, and they were expanding these.
School of Veterinary Medicine at the time, and there was a need for a department they called Veterinary Hygiene.
Whether that's a good term or not was questionable.
What exactly does it mean?
Well, that's it.
What does it mean?
They argued that.
Lots of them said it didn't make any sense and whatnot.
And finally, it evolved into veterinary public health.
What they actually tried to, well, make it was veterinary subjects related to human health.
For example?
Like milk hygiene, meat hygiene, and that type of thing.
And that disease is transmissible from animal to man.
But the choice of veterinary hygiene seemed to not fit the bill.
So eventually it was changed.
Why did they affect you?
I don't know.
They were looking for somebody, and I was in practice.
I guess they couldn't find anybody else.
That's the only thing I know.
How can you account for expansion during the Depression?
1937 was a bad year in American history.
Well, I had nothing to do with the accounting for it.
I was employed during the Depression, which is getting towards the tail end of the Depression.
And I was in practice there in Beaumont and working for the city doing food hygiene work.
So I guess they were scouting around for somebody.
Could you
Explain your duties as the head of the department, teaching and research and things like that.
No, I didn't do any research.
I did develop courses in milk hygiene, meat hygiene, and I did the
meat inspection at the meats laboratory over in the animal husbandry department.
How about teaching?
I taught a little of everything.
Of course, the two courses I mentioned, and then I also taught infectious diseases, large animal infectious diseases, and
I'd fill in teaching non-infectious diseases, obstetrics, or what have you, for other departments where they had conflicts because they were short-handed.
And sometimes they'd have conflicts or overloads, and I would teach some of these other courses.
I'd assist with the operative surgery.
because the classes had gotten pretty big by then, and Dr. Leonard was teaching surgery, and then in the laboratory when they were doing their laboratory work, I'd help with the surgery.
I'd help him with his surgery so we could give more individual attention to the students.
One man with about 30 men
doing surgery could very well supervise, so I helped him with that.
One other course I didn't mention, I also taught a course for agricultural students in animal hygiene.
I have a question about your job as the head of Veterinarian Hygiene.
You had that position from 1937 to 1949, 12 years.
What changes did you witness during those years in that department?
Well, I guess one thing, we finally got a laboratory where we could do what laboratory work we needed to do with
meat and milk, hygiene, and outside of that, during the war and after the war, since we went year-round, didn't have too many changes, except we had to double up on our teaching.
Every subject was taught every term, and consequently, we were too busy to do
make too many changes.
Well what about them thinking about changes as far as the course load?
Did it increase or decrease?
Or as far as the curriculum, were there new courses offered that hadn't been offered before?
Or as far as new people being hired, was there an increase in faculty during those years under your direction?
Oh yeah, not under my direction, no.
But in the veterinary school there was an increase.
departments were well divided up to make other departments.
In other words, parasitology became a department, and it recently was part of another department.
I've forgotten what they called it now, but the man that taught parasitology also taught
histology and pathology and food hygiene, and then they divided the, divided it up, made it a department of parasitology, which took some of the load off of that.
I was trying to think now,
Anatomy stayed like it was, but they employed two, three more people, a couple more people, and pathology was pulled out into a department, and microbiology was pulled out into a department.
Now, why were they?
Why were these changes?
Why were they?
Yeah.
Why did these changes come about?
Because had more students, too many students, and had need for more faculty.
And it was expansion.
That's it.
Now during of course 1941 and 1945, this nation was consumed in the Second World War.
I was wondering what was it like being at Texas A&M, and especially in the School of Medicine during the Second World War?
Well on campus, we had lots of lots of servicemen.
They had, they were there for short periods of time.
In other words, with the
teaching them something on an intensive basis, and most of us in veterinary school had nothing to do with that.
We did have some students that were, I've forgotten what they called it now, Student Army Training Corps, something of that nature.
Different from the Corps of Cadets, huh?
Yes, yes.
and these were to go into the service as soon as they graduated, and we had some of them.
Now, in the veterinary school, we did not have many in the Corps of Cadets.
Most of them were non-military students, I guess you'd call them, because a good many of them were
were older or didn't have time really to enter into a bunch of extracurricular activities.
I shouldn't say extracurricular because military science wouldn't be, but most of them were, you might say, civilian students, and I don't know what else I can say about that.
Did the living conditions decline in any way because of the war and because of the material needed for the war?
No, it didn't affect the veterinary school much, any.
How about the general funding?

Was the support for the veterinarian school decreased and shifted other ways, or did you get a feeling that the administration thought that veterinarian medicine was now at least as important or as important as it had been before the war?

Well, I think they, as it became more popular and more students or more individuals wanted to take veterinary medicine, I think they did become an awareness of the importance of veterinary medicine, or that it was more important than they had thought at one time.

course it goes back a long ways where they used to talk about the farriers being the veterinarians and so on, and but it became a little more respected and recognized as time went on, and as the curriculum
became more exact and not so broad and not just clinical subjects, but as I went into research and that sort of thing, became specialized in certain cases.
like poultry diseases and things of that nature, why it did become better recognized.
And because we had such a, well, it was a tough curriculum, it was respected to a large extent on that account.
Beyond that, I don't know anything I can tell you.

Okay, I was thinking about the Second World War and the effect that there must, the war itself must have had some effect or the immediate post-war situation must have had some effect on, on the School of Veterinary Medicine.
Do you, do you think it did or?
I don't know how to analyze that.

Obviously, it did have some effect because the men, as they graduated, most of them got commissions and went into the service, and then a lot of those finally served their years in the service and reached retirement
and came back out, some of them to teach and some of them to go into other lines of work that they had become proficient in in the service.
So, it had its effect.
I don't know that I could put my finger on it and say it affected this in such and such a way, but certainly in the case of
the Department of Veterinary Hygiene, it had lots of effect because the veterinarians that went into the service, a big part of them, were hygienists.
And then they came out and a lot of them, while they were in the service, got a Masters of Public Health,
and some even beyond that, and so there became an awareness of the importance of the veterinarian as far as food hygiene was concerned.
So it had an effect on this department in that respect.
Now probably in other departments it wasn't as noticeable.

In 1936, right before you came here, in order to get into Veterinarian Medicine, School of Veterinarian Medicine, one needed 15 hours of pre-professional work, and in 1975 that was increased to 66 hours of pre-professional work.
Why is that?
Why were the requirements so small, and now why are they so much larger?
I guess it's because of the development of more research, the things that have caused these subjects to become more technical, and because
medicine, knowledge of medicine has increased in the last 20 years to the extent that it takes more training to fit into the niche.
And has this increase in requirements to get into the School of Vet and Medicine had, have you seen any difference between the students, or does it make better students, or?
Do you have any idea on that?
Does it make better veterinarians?
Is it worthwhile?
Well, it should.
All I can say is it should.
Bear in mind that I've been out of the field for 15 years.
Yeah, of course.
And there's been tremendous strides since I retired from college veterinary medicine.
And consequently, those men are definitely better trained than those before them.
So, well, there's been, I know when I first came to the college there,
Practically all the drugs we used were just basic drugs, and finally sulfanilamides came on, and then antibiotics, and all that type of thing has had a tremendous influence on what and how you teach.

In other words, we used to use arsenic in one form or another for this and that and the other, and most of those basic drugs now that were a lot of mineral, a lot of plant extracts, have been replaced by other things, maybe synthetics in some cases.
and there's been tremendous strides in the knowledge of surgery and orthopedics and that sort of thing.
So, they have to be better trained.
Now, whether as individuals they're any better is something else, but at least their training is
much better than it used to be.

Now, during your almost 30 years at the College of Veterinary Medicine, did you feel during that time, if you can reflect on this, that the students, the incoming first-year students, were better students, more knowledgeable students than those in the 1930s?
Well, yes, because we got to the point where we screened them.
And then it became more or less competitive.
We had more applicants than we could take, and so we'd interview them, and in various ways we would rank them, and consequently a lot of them never got in.
The ones we thought were not up to par.
What was the criteria for ranking these students and, for example, in the interview?
Well, a big part of it was their pre-veterinary record.
Yeah.
And then the rest, we tried to try to determine background and
desire or why they wanted veterinary medicine, and the type of practice they wanted to go into, and then, let's say, just opinion of the selection committee.
Each one, each one would, would rank them.
and then you'd get a composite, and here you'd come up with a figure.
Did you think that system worked well?
Yes, it did at that time.
It's been changed a lot since then.
In what way?
I don't know.
All I know is it's been changed a lot.
See, I haven't had any contact with it.
In 1962, before you retired,
180 students applied for vet school, and today somewhere around 600 students are applying for vet school.
There seems to be a great new interest in becoming a veterinarian.
Why do you think that is?
Do you have any opinions on that?
Well, I think probably for one thing, as we got more graduates,

out into the field, and because of numbers, and we feel they were all good men, and had more influence in their community that lots of boys or girls or lots of students, let's call them, thought it was fascinating.
that the profession was fascinating, and they wanted to go into it.
Now it used to be that practically all of them went into large animal practice, and then the small animal was sidelined.
Now there's a predominance of small animal practitioners where they can live in the city and
have lots of conveniences that the large animal practitioner didn't have in the small community.
And of course the passing of the horse had a lot to do with it.
So there's been lots of influences of that nature, but I think as the government has had lots to do with
promoting veterinary medicine.
In what way?

Well, they had moving pictures that would promote the profession and then they became the old Bureau of Animal Industries grew and grew and grew and they had these animal disease research facilities like Plum Island and
the one in Iowa and whatnot.
So, it's just a question of people becoming better acquainted with what the profession had to offer.
And I think a lot of it, too, is that they feel like when they graduate they're going to be independent.
Yeah.
They won't be working for
General Electric or the telephone company or something like that, but they'll be out independent and everybody likes independence.
I think that's a big part of it too.
The first woman came, the first woman student came to Texas A&M School of Vet Medicine
at 1963, right before you retired, and now they comprise about one-third of the student body.
I was wondering what your feelings were when the first woman came.
What did you think of that?
Do you remember?
No, I remember, I remember her, and what was her name?
I don't remember.
I've got it written down, but I don't know.
She was a very attractive, black-headed girl, married, and I think went into practice with her husband in Lubbock.
I believe that's right.
But anyway, I never had her in class, and I don't know, it was kind of strange to me.
that would have women wanting to practice veterinary medicine, and some of them go into large animal practice, which is pretty hard for me to understand.
Of course, they want equal rights now, and apparently they'll have to register for the draft like everybody else, so if they want equal rights, they'll have to pay penalties.
What was the general faculty, do you remember what the general faculty response to admitting women was back in the early 1960s?
What did you and your colleagues think about having women students?
I don't think we resented it too much.
We thought it was strange that they'd want to take veterinary medicine, but if they wanted it, I don't think we resented it.
In other words, you don't think there was really much decision?
No.
Not much dissent.
because and then it was just what two or three came along there and didn't amount to much, but now I guess it's uh they just take their knocks along with the with the boys.
Do you know, I haven't been able to find out much information about this, I know that the first women came in 1963, but how'd they make the decision to allow them to enter?
That I don't know.
I don't know where I can talk to you about that.
I don't really know that either.
I guess about that time, about that time they removed the restrictions of taking women into A&M.
It became coeducational.
So I guess it just had to be part of that.
Now that's just
my opinion.
I don't know that that's really the case, but if the university wanted to go co-educational, veterinary medicine couldn't say no.
What did you think of the quality of these first women students?
They were good.
As far as I know, as I say, I didn't have- Didn't you ever have, I mean, two years later you resigned, so you didn't have a woman in any class?
No, I didn't have anything but seniors.
Okay, okay, right.
And consequently, they got up to meet this first one, I think graduated the next year.
Yeah.
I believe.
A woman in a previously all-male setting must have had some impact on the School of Veterinary Medicine.
Well, it wasn't apparent.
There wasn't enough of them while I was out there for it to be apparent.
Okay, I'd like to, now that we're talking about women, I'd like to switch to another topic, and that is
concerning blacks in veterinary medicine.
We have a number of blacks on campus today, and I'm rather surprised, well, I'd like your opinion on this.
I don't want to editorialize.
I'd like your opinion on this.
Why are there so few blacks in veterinary medicine?
Do you have an idea on them?
I had never thought about it.
No.
At one time, down at Prairie View, they had a department of veterinary medicine.
And the head of that department down there was a good veterinarian and a fine man.
But the blacks would go there and just, they'd have a few courses in veterinary medicine and they didn't get a degree.
And, of course, schools were segregated then, and I can't answer your question.
We didn't have one when I was out there.
I know, I know.
It's a difficult question, and today I don't know if there's any blacks enrolled at all.
Veterinary medicine?
I don't know if there are.
There might be one or two.
They did have some.
Uh-huh.
They did have some.
Shortly after I retired, I know they had some out there.
Now, I think a lot of that, this is not for publication, I think a lot of that was due to insistence by the NAACP
that Negroes go to A&M and go into the veterinary school and invade every area in the country.
Now, whether they could cut the mustard or not, the students were something else, but they did push them.
